note.name: -READING THIS ADVENTURE
note.text:
This adventure is written for 3-5 characters at level 20, forming an adventure of epic level and consequence. These pages will provide notes for adjusting the difficulty based on party size at the end (see Appendix E).
Intended as a one-shot, single session adventure (around 3-5 hours), this can instead be dropped into most existing settings and/or campaigns.
Please read this entire adventure before playing, to ensure everything is understood and prepared for.
At the end of this document, after the adventure, you will find several appendices, providing supplementary information such as stat blocks. Additionally, five pre-generated character sheets can be found after the appendices. These are not required to enjoy this adventure, but are available for those that wish to use them.

note.name: -PREMISE
note.text:
Entering a mysterious ruin, the party finds cryptic inscriptions and warnings carved into the stone walls.
Moving deeper, they discover a massive cavern, filled with stone rubble and gargantuan statues. As they watch, two of these statues come to life, revealing a Copper Dragon and a Green Dragon, both clearly ancient.
As a standoff ensues, the party learns that they have triggered an ancient trap. Having been cursed by entering, they will find themselves forced to choose sides as more dragons awaken, leading to an epic battle testing their fears, abilities, and even their very alignments.

note.name: THE RAVEN’S NEST
note.text: The local bar and inn, the Raven’s Nest is well-kept and busy each night. Many down-on-their-luck men and women have found the mental willpower and motivation to push forward after spending a night here, pouring their hearts out to the kind barkeep.

note.name: -THE MISSING FARMER
note.text:
Traversing the countryside, the party enters a small village, living in the shadow of a large mountain.
Opening in a tavern, the party is eating and drinking the night away. Speaking to the locals, the evening is light-hearted and fun until a dour middle-aged man enters the bar. Eyebrows furrowed and eyes puffy from lack of sleep, this man takes a seat in a lonely corner of the bar, quietly ordering a drink from the bartender.
This man is Carlos Alves Sousa, as described in Appendix A. The mood in the tavern becomes a bit less joyful as he takes his seat, and an Insight check (DC 13) will show that people are not afraid - in fact, they seem to pity him.
If the party asks about Carlos, they’ll be sadly (and quietly) told a simple story: Carlos’s brother Rodrigo recently went up to the mountain, chasing ancient rumors of great treasure. Many people have sought this treasure throughout the years, but none have ever returned... including Rodrigo. Due to the fabled curse upon the mountain, he is presumed dead.
Carlos had begged him not to go, but Rodrigo didn’t listen, wanting to help his impoverished older brother afford better farm tools. Now in mourning, Carlos blames himself for his brother’s death.
Hopefully, this will be enough to entice the party up the mountain to explore for themselves. If for any reason they seem uninterested, the bartender (Marcos, also detailed in Appendix A) will quietly approach the party, of a modest amount of gold for this expedition, mostly to cover costs of food and supplies - including a small handful of Potions of Healing or Potions of Greater Healing, if desired. These can be purchased from another shop in town (Appendix B).

note.name: MATEO’S MERCANTILE
note.text: Your average general store, this place contains basic supplies such as climbing gear, rations, canteens, and even a few Potions of Healing. No other enchanted items are available here.

note.name: THE SNOWY MOUNTAIN
note.text:
Stretching high into the clouds, this mountain may not be comparable to Everest, but it does provide a steep climb for those willing to spare a day to climb it.
Not much plant life grows in the high snowy areas, which means fewer animals bother to venture that far up the mountain.

note.name: -A MYSTERIOUS RUIN
note.text:
Resting and gearing up, the party will ascend the mountain. If desired, you can describe the rough terrain and dangerous cliff that must be scaled along the way, requiring Athletics checks (DC 15) to climb successfully.
Any who fail this check will slip, potentially falling. If the party has thought to use climbing gear or rope, perhaps tying themselves together, require a Strength saving throw (DC 15) from the next party member as their body weight tugs at them suddenly. If this party member fails their check, move on to the next, increasing the DC. They may find themselves each pulled from the ciffs if they’re not careful!
If they did not use rope or find themselves falling anyway, these characters will take 3d6 bludgeoning damage as they fall around 25-30 feet, landing hard on the gravel below.
Continuing the climb, they will eventually reach an area near the top, where they find an immense cave entrance. Over one hundred feet wide and tall, they may not realize it, but this cave is big enough for an ancient dragon to fly through... or worse, something bigger.

note.name: THE YAWNING CORRIDOR
note.text:
Large in size and covered in ribbons of flowing script, these carvings have faded over years of wind erosion.
Nearly a mile in length, a creature trapped inside would need to fully exit this cave entrance into the outside world if they wish to escape the curse.

note.name: -STRANGE WARNINGS
note.text:
Allow them a short rest near the cave entrance if they wish. A full day hasn’t passed, so it’s a bit too early for a long rest (not that they need it) Assuming they began their trek at dawn, it’s likely noon by now - perhaps a couple hours later if they struggled or have lower walking speeds.
Entering the cavern, it doesn’t take long before carvings start to gradually take form from the rough rock. Although ancient, it is clear that these walls, floors, and ceiling were all polished smooth once, many centuries or millennia ago.
On these now-crumbling walls, the party will find strange hieroglyphs and writing. Some of it is illegible due to sections of the wall falling away, and others are in unknown runic languages.
However, a History check (DC 18) will allow a character to recognize sections which resemble the languages of the Giants and the Abyss, along with various pieces of Elemental languages. Realizing this is a form of Primordial, any character who speaks this language will require only a History check of DC 13 to read it.
Oddly cryptic and foreign, this Primordial writing seems to be an early dialect, potentially pre-dating anything else they’ve ever seen. If this writing can be translated, the players will find odd warnings and stories of some terrible monster or being, which is never fully described or explained.
Disturbingly, as the party presses forward, the clearest phrases soon shift from warnings to stay away to pleadings to never leave. Eerie and spine-chilling, these glyphs now seem determined to convince them that they will spend eternity within these halls.

note.name: THE COLOSSAL CHAMBER
note.text: Enormous in size, this place must have taken years to carve out. Even with magic, it would still take months and dozens of magic users, speaking to a truly impressive power wielded by the creators... especially considering the horrors trapped beneath the once-polished stone floors.

note.name: -CAVERN OF STATUES
note.text:
After walking a fair distance, the party eventually reaches a point where the already-massive passage opens up into an incredible cavern. Big enough to house a town - perhaps a city - this cavern is several hundred feet tall, stretching far into the darkness opposite the entry tunnel.
With dozens of immense stone pillars, this room - for it is a room, as your highest Passive Perception characters soon notice - has been carefully carved, with the same once-smooth walls, floors, and ceilings as the entrance tunnel.
However, eons of time have caused several pillars to crumble, allowing various stone debris and sections of the ceiling above to scatter below, forming massive blockages in the central areas of the room.
Along the walls, dirt and sand has begun to collect, as if massive winds pushed ancient piles of rock and dust against them.
Looking ahead, the party begins to see several gargantuan shapes in the darkness between the pillars, unmoving.
Approaching, these are clearly life-size statues of ancient dragons. As the party comes closer, a resounding crack echoes through the room, followed by the cacophonous sound of grating stone.

note.name: -WE SHOULD NOT HAVE COME
note.text:
As the party watches on, two of these statues quickly spring to life, their rock prisons cracking open and crumbling around their feet. Battle-scarred and clearly dangerous, one of these is an Ancient Green Dragon, while the other is an Ancient Copper Dragon.
Roaring at each other, the sound causes the floor to quake, as dust drifts from the ceiling above. With multiple sparks of blue light, several of their open wounds begin to close, clearly being healed by an unknown, powerful magic.
Noticing the party, the Copper Dragon will growl, moving to protect them from the Green Dragon. Standing between them, this dragon will speak. “You should have heeded the warnings,” he rumbles, before continuing. “But it’s too late now. This prison houses terrible evil, and I stand as protector. If you wish to protect this world, let none escape this place.”
As the party readies to assist him (presuming a good-aligned party) or begins to speak, the Green Dragon begins to cackle with grating laughter. Interrupting the party if they are clearly planning to aid the Copper Dragon, the Green Dragon will choose their words carefully if the party hesitates.
“Fools. If you aid him, this place will become your prison also! For the curse to remain, none may leave... including you.”
As the Green Dragon speaks, allow a Perception check (DC 13). On a success a party member will notice faint movement in the corner of the room. Rock still crumbling from his shoulders and back, a man with similar facial features to Carlos is sneaking toward the exit, ducking behind pillars. Looking terrified, he motions for the party to stay silent.
However, both dragons quickly notice him. Eyes flicking in his direction, the Green Dragon continues speaking. “Are you prepared to spend eternity defending this place? Because that is what he asks of you.”
As Rodrigo bolts for the exit in a mad dash, the Copper Dragon roars, beating his wings. Forcing everyone nearby (within 15 feet) to make a Dexterity saving throw (DC 23), any who fail are knocked prone, taking 2d6+8 bludgeoning damage.
As they watch on in horror, Rodrigo is sent flying, crumpling against a pillar in a heap. Clearly dead, the party witnesses his skin slowly become stone once more.

note.name: -CHOOSING SIDES
note.text:
At this point, the party has limited time to choose sides before the other dragons awaken and Initiative is rolled.
Having just seen a good-aligned dragon kill an innocent man, a party who typically opposes evil may be stunned, unsure of who to help.
Allow them a couple quick questions, but keep answers brief, with both dragons attempting to sway them to their side.

note.name: -THE DRAGONS AWAKEN
note.text:
As can be quickly explained, any chromatic dragons present entered without knowing of the curse, planning to make this place their new lair.
Wise metallic dragons who knew the truth recognized the threat posed if a chromatic dragon escaped, and slowly gathered over time to prevent anyone from leaving, as is the point of the stone curse - to collect ‘immortal’ guardians, revived through the ages to defend the prison.
With the basic details, the party must choose. As the party aligns with either the chromatic or metallic dragons, this choice will affect the upcoming battle.
As more cracks echo through the chamber, several more dragons begin to awaken in the further reaches of the room. Too far for the party to interfere, one awakened dragon will crash through three other stone dragons, destroying and killing them - after all, the only way to die within this chamber is to have your statue broken. These three slain dragons are of the same type aligned with the party, leaving two allied dragons against five opposing (one CR 21/22 and one CR 23/24 - your choice). For example, if the party decides to align with the Green Dragon (whatever their reasons), three chromatic dragons will be destroyed, leaving the party with only two chromatic allies against five metallic enemies.
This balances this encounter, as dragons would quickly tear each other apart in a boring battle if their numbers were even. This way, the dragons need the party if they wish to succeed.

note.name: -RUNNING THIS ENCOUNTER
note.text:
Rolling for Initiative, be sure to roll separately for each dragon. This will help space their turns throughout those of your party, so they don’t get bored.
With seven dragons and 3-5 players, there are 10-12 turns each round. With Legendary Actions, dragons are able to act after another creature’s turn, which could bog down combat if used poorly. To avoid this, only allow two Legendary Actions per turn. This way, you won’t get distracted, keeping each turn manageable. Even with ten turns per round, this means only a single Legendary Action will go unspent, which could be used for a Wing Attack if you’d like a 3-Action round. Even still, you’ll need to be quick. Decide which Dragons will take Legendary Actions next as your players take their turns, to keep things moving.
Additionally, keep in mind that if a Legendary Action costs two actions, that’s it for the round! Two counts as two, whether two dragons make Tail Attacks or one is making a Wing Attack. This can be a deadly encounter for your players if they’re not careful, or if the dice don’t go their way. But, that’s the fun of an Epic Level adventure - high stakes!
To help you keep track of everything, we’ve provided cheat sheets in Appendix F, detailing each dragon and info you’ll need during battle.
Although full stats are provided in Appendix C, you likely won’t need them if you use the cheat sheets instead.

note.name: =ALLIES OF CONSEQUENCE
note.text:
Keep in mind, their allies do matter. All the chromatic dragons need to do in order to win is escape, which means the metallic dragons are going to be playing defense, trying to prevent anyone from leaving.
Additionally, the chromatic dragons aren’t exactly allies here, unlike the unified metallic dragons. If a breath weapon or Wing Attack accidentally hits another chromatic dragon or even a member of the party, they won’t really care. Their own survival is of the utmost importance.
Also, feel free to substitute in Gem Dragons from Fizban’s Treasury of Dragons if you like, or even other dragon types if that sounds fun!

note.name: =MORALITY TWIST
note.text:
If you’d like to put an interesting morality spin on this adventure, you could even have the lawful chromatic dragons (Blue and Green) ally themselves with the lawful metallic dragons (Bronze, Gold, and Silver).
For this scenario, providing an interesting twist, lawful evil dragons may recognize the danger of allowing anything to escape the chamber, thus working together with unlikely allies. Meanwhile more chaotic dragons may view themselves as strong enough to escape or defeat the coming apocalypse themselves, causing a strange clash of alignment.

note.name: -PURPOSE... OR DOOM
note.text:
Having defeated their enemies, the party still has an important choice to make. They’re free to change their minds, after all... however, the guardian dragons might require convincing to allow this. If failed, the party may find themselves fighting their once-allies for their desired freedom.
Are they willing to remain here as protectors, preventing the apocalypse for eternity? It’s a worthy purpose.
Or, is the party willing to risk it all, unleashing chaos upon the world on the gamble that they can defeat it?
This is a battle they might not win. Are they truly strong enough to stop the apocalypse? Or will their hubris doom this world forever?

note.name: MOVING FORWARD
note.text:
Greater Restoration can cure Rodrigo of his petrification. If they all survive the end of the world, he might be able to return to his brother, with treasure left behind by the dragons.
If they choose to stay, Wish or Divine Intervention may be enough to save a player character. However, some may be left behind to their new destiny, if they desire it.
So, what will these heroes choose? To tempt the fates, or to partake in eternal battle? Either way, there will be consequences...

note.name: THE END
note.text: With that, you’ve reached the ending of this one-shot adventure. Thank you for reading! I hope you enjoyed it. There will be many more to come (including a sequel), so keep an eye out.
